text: Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has ordered the ACCC to “lift the hood on the internal workings of the banks” after consumers lodged a flood of complaints. The Treasurer asked the ACCC to conduct an investigation after the sector snubbed its nose at the RBA and refused to pass rate cuts in full. Mr Frydenberg said an inquiry would be “focused on the residential mortgage market and particularly why the banks have not passed on these rate cuts in full”. Mr Frydenberg told Sky News “ultimately consumers must come first” so the probe will be launched “to understand why there is such a big difference between what is charged to a loyal customer and what is charged to a new customer that the banks are trying to win over”. “Ultimately, it’s the consumers who are worse off because if these three most recent rate cuts had been passed on in full, then someone with a $400,000 mortgage would be paying $500 less a year in interest payments,” he said.
